docs.lead_paragraph: A CENTURY ago girls belonging to the upper, professional and middle classes were expected to get married, and were under very heavy penalties if they failed to do so. To a very large proportion of them marriage was the only career open; it was, in fact, regarded as a means of livelihood and a preservative against want, and was adopted as such in a perfectly simple and straightforward manner.

headline.main: Change in the Sentiment Toward Marriage Since Girls Are Brought Up for Business or Profession.

docs.lead_paragraph: IN the very important subject of infantile mortality, which affects the United States as well as other countries of the world, the great peculiar fact exists that we are talking continually about the possible decrease in our birth-rate, yet we are not conserving the life of the babies who are here.
